content:
Diagnosis:	Metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma with mixed small cell features

Management:	Jan 2024 Started Docetaxel/ADT
		March 2024 Emergency admission with seizures - brain metastases identified
		March 2024 Whole brain radiotherapy 20Gy/5#

Current Status:	Progressive disease with neurological deterioration

I reviewed [redacted name] today who was accompanied by his wife and daughter. Unfortunately, his condition has significantly deteriorated since our last review. His performance status has declined from 1 to 3, and he is now predominantly bed-bound requiring assistance with most activities of daily living. He has experienced increased confusion and unsteady gait despite completing whole brain radiotherapy last month. His wife reports he has fallen twice in the past week.

His bone pain has also worsened, particularly in the thoracic spine and left hip, now requiring regular breakthrough analgesia. Recent blood tests show PSA has risen further to 892 despite castrate testosterone levels. Latest CT shows progressive bone metastases and new liver lesions. MRI brain shows mixed response to radiotherapy with some lesions showing progression.

Given the rapid progression and emergence of mixed small cell features on recent biopsy, I have discussed his case with colleagues. We recommend transitioning to platinum-based chemotherapy with carboplatin/etoposide. However, given his current performance status, we need to carefully consider his fitness for further systemic therapy.

I have referred him to our palliative care team for urgent review and arranged admission to our oncology ward for assessment and symptom control. We will review treatment options once his symptoms are better controlled. I have also arranged an urgent OT assessment and increased his dexamethasone to 8mg BD.

His wife understands the seriousness of the situation and agrees with focusing on symptom control as the immediate priority.
